elements.text: I want a very simple middleware that simply tells me if the client is logged in or not. Basically "does req.user exist?" But if I use the below code, it prints "not logged in" but does not allow the page to load. What is the solution? I'm combing through the req JSON but it's massive

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_preformatted","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"function user(req, res, next) {\n  req.user ? console.log(\"logged in\") : console.log(\"Not logged in.\");\n}"}],"border":0}

text: I think you have to call "next" in the end, otherwise there is no next... (?)

elements.text: I think you have to call "next" in the end, otherwise there is no next... (?)

text: hmm, I see that I need to call next() but I don't want to. I want to return a boolean based on if req.user even exists. In order to render the page differently and not redirect.

so to sum up – checking/getting the user out from the req object can take a couple of forms, depending on where/how you put it in
where / how you put it in depends on your login/signup implementations.

this makes not much sense if you really think about it.

text: if it's a middleware -> then you should make the redirect/next calls explicit. not return a boolean.

elements.text: if it's a middleware -> then you should make the redirect/next calls explicit. not return a boolean.

text: ah okay

elements.text: ah okay

text: if it's a function that you want to use within route handlers to check if user is authenticated -> then don't use a middleware.

elements.text: if it's a function that you want to use within route handlers to check if user is authenticated -> then don't use a middleware.

text: you can see that this is what req.isAuthenticated is in the code I posted above.

text: it's simply a function, returning true/false

elements.text: it's simply a function, returning true/false

text: but generally in terms of "best" practices, this sounds like something you would want to have in a middleware. :slightly_smiling_face: i.e. something that changes the routing behavior in different places and is reusable => middleware!

text:
yup pretty much what Bernd sent. :100:

now the thing is, you might want different redirects from different pages and stuff. in this case you could make the middleware configurable by using a closure :wink:

i.e. a function that returns the middleware, kinda like a middleware "factory" :slightly_smiling_face:

text: just wanted to say that, because middlewares are quite flexible/powerful because they *are* functions in the end :slightly_smiling_face:

text:
hmmm that works... but why make things so complicated?

you can just use req.isAuthenticated ANYWHERE in your route handlers directly.

so where you now do req.userStatus === "visitor" stuff you could just do an !req.isAuthenticated() instead :man-shrugging:

elements.text:
hmmm that works... but why make things so complicated?

you can just use req.isAuthenticated ANYWHERE in your route handlers directly.

so where you now do req.userStatus === "visitor" stuff you could just do an !req.isAuthenticated() instead
